For example, consider the rational number 5\/74:.. 0.0675 74 5.00000 4.44 560 518 420 370 500 etc. Observe that at each step we have a remainder; the successive remainders"}, {"name": "Fractions with prime denominators", "url": "https:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Repeating_decimal#Fractions_with_prime_denominators", "snippet": "A fraction in lowest terms with a prime denominator other than 2 or 5 always produces a repeating decimal. The length of the repetend of 1\/p is equal to the order of 10 modulo p. If 10 is a primitive root modulo p, the repetend length is equal to p − 1; if not, the repetend length is a factor of p − 1. This result can be deduced from Fermat's little theorem, which states that 10p−1 ≡ 1. The base-10 repetend of the reciprocal of any prime number greater than 5 is divisible by 9. If ..."}, {"name": "Reciprocals of composite integers coprime to 10", "url": "https:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Repeating_decimal#Reciprocals_of_composite_integers_coprime_to_10", "snippet": "If p is a prime other than 2 or 5, the decimal representation of the fraction 1 p 2 {\\displaystyle {\\tfrac {1}{p^{2}}}} repeats, e.g.: 1\/49 = 0.020408163265306122448 979591836734693877551."}, {"name": "Reciprocals of integers not co-prime to 10", "url": "https:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Repeating_decimal#Reciprocals_of_integers_not_co-prime_to_10", "snippet": "An integer that is not co-prime to 10 but has a prime factor other than 2 or 5 has a reciprocal that is eventually periodic, but with a non-repeating sequence of digits that precede the repeating part.
